item.description: 1.2 Probability Theory Consider two random variables $X,Y$ where $X$ can take any of the values $x_i$ where $i=1,2,…,M$ and $Y$ can take the values $y_j$ where $j=1,2,…,L$. In a total of $N$ trials, both $X,Y$ are sampled and the number of trials for which $X=x_i,Y=y_j$ is $n_{ij}$. The number of trials in which $X=x_i$ is $c_i$ and $Y=y_j$ is $r_j$ respectively.
